reviewText: This show is not the same without Vivian Vance.  Mr. Mooney always yelling and getting hysterical gets annoying after a while.  The show has no direction anymore because there is no consistency to the writing.  It is a mistake not to mention Lucy's onscreen kids Jerry and Chris.  Jerry makes two final appearances in the episodes "Lucy at Marineland" and "Lucy the Choirmaster".  He is never to be seen or referred to again.Also, stars walking into Lucy's life consistently boxes the series in.  There are some good episodes and even some superior ones.  I love the "Wing DIng" episode, "Lucy Discovers Wayne Newton", the one where Lucy and the Countess become spies, "Lucy the Robot" and "Lucy Bags a Bargain"...but ther rest of the series ranges from mediocre to just o.k.Lucy is just plain annoying when she's Iron Man Carmichael.  THe episodes with Dean Martin and Bob Crane are terrible.  What I loved as a child I now realize is just silly.  Its not Lucy's fault.  She is always a joy but her writers are just terrible.....they changed the "Lucy" character into someone dumb and stupid....Lucy Ricardo was never stupid...she was clever, conniving, and smart!  And so was Lucy Carmichael in the Viv years.  But this so-so season is just that...so-so.  Thus, the three star rating...not bad...not great...just so-so....its just not the same without Viv.
summary: Not the Same Without Viv
Title: N/A

reviewText: The fourth season marks a serious break from the previous three seasons of "The Lucy Show."  Previously, Lucy was living in Westchester County, New York with her daughter Chris (Candy Moore) and son Jerry (Jimmy Garrett); her friend Vivian Bagley (Vivian Vance) and her son Sherman (Ralph Hart).  Now all of these cast members are gone and Lucy has moved to Los Angeles.  Coincidentally, so has the banker who oversees Lucy's trust fund, Theodore J. Mooney (Gale Gordon).  Lucy has a new best friend named Mary Jane (Mary Jane Croft, who previously played a different character back in New York).Lucy soon goes to work for Mr. Mooney at the bank, and her trust fund is never mentioned again.  Most of the episodes center on Lucy getting in trouble at the office or scheming to involve various celebrities in her life.  (Part of the reason the show moved from suburban New York to Hollywood was so all these celebrity encounters would seem more plausible.)  Lucy even has a recurring job as a stunt player in the movies.The fourth season definitely shows that Lucy can make it on her own without a large supporting cast.I highly recommendThe Lucy Book: A Complete Guide to Her Five Decades on Televisionby Geoffrey Mark Fidelman as a viewing companion to anything with Lucille Ball.
summary: New format for "The Lucy Show"
Title: N/A

reviewText: The fourth year of THE LUCY SHOW was a period of change in many ways.  Not only did the series switch locales from small-town Danfield to the hustle of California, but Lucy also had to shoulder the load of the entire series without the presence of her long-time sidekick Vivian Vance.  Ms Vance had actually started to cut back her appearances during the third season, citing the tiring commute between her New York home and the Desilu studios in California as the main reason for leaving.In Season Four, Lucy Carmichael (Lucille Ball) makes the bold step of moving to California.  In a passing comment she mentions that Viv has re-married; whilst Lucy's daughter Chris is now in college.  After enrolling her son Jerry (Jimmy Garrett) in a military academy--Harvey Korman is the Major--she winds up working as the secretary for her old Danfield nemesis Mr Mooney (Gale Gordon), who has also inexplicably made the move to the West Coast.Lucy experimented with 2 possible 'Viv'-type replacements in Season Four, namely Joan Blondell (who played Joan Brenner, one of Lucy's new neighbours) and the return of Ann Sothern as Rosie Harrigan, aka the Countess Framboise, but neither quite worked out.  In the case of Ms Blondell, Ball found her comedic rapport to be, putting it mildly, rather lacking.  Whilst Ms Sothern would have been the ideal replacement for Vance, she'd have requested the all-important "co-starring" billing which Ball was reluctant to share.  So for any episodes which called for one of Lucy's girlfriends, good ole reliable Mary Jane Croft was used.In any case, the three episodes with Ann Sothern as the Countess are a complete joy.  You can really see the delight with which Ball and Sothern play opposite each other.  Their friendship stretched back to Ball's early Hollywood days as a Goldwyn Girl, when Ms Sothern, then one of Hollywood's reigning young glamour queens, helped out Lucy with decorating her first real home in California.  Lucy later made a crossover appearance as 'Lucy Ricardo' on Sothern's sitcom "The Ann Sothern Show", and Ann returned the favour when she played 'Susie MacNamara' in a special episode of the "Lucy-Desi Comedy Hour".Sothern's first episode of Season Four, "Lucy and the Countess Have a Horse Guest", also features what became William Frawley's last ever screen appearance.  He has a special walk-on role as a stablehand, and shares a special moment with Lucy.  It's a bittersweet moment for "Lucy" fans.  There's additional fun to be had with Lucy and the Countess in "Lucy Helps the Countess", which culminates in the pair - plus Mr Mooney - getting accidentally locked overnight in an empty apartment.  In "Lucy and the Undercover Agent", Lucy and the Countess, obsessed with James Bond films, are convinced that they have uncovered a foreign spy syndicate.  Lucy performs an hilarious impersonation of Carol Channing.Season Four is where the stars really come out to play in THE LUCY SHOW.  Sure, there had been guest stars in seasons 1-3, but given that California now acted as the backdrop of the show (just like when "I Love Lucy" went Hollywood in Seasons 4 and 5), it was the perfect excuse for Lucy to invite her considerable collection of celebrity pals to clown along with her.  Guests for Season Four include Danny Thomas, Mickey Rooney, Jimmy Piersall, Milton Berle, Wayne Newton, Art Linkletter, Kirk Douglas, Edward G. Robinson, Dean Martin, Bob Crane, Clint Walker; Robert Stack and some of his co-stars from "The Untouchables".  The season opener, "Lucy at Marineland", also has fun roles for Ball's real-life children Desi Jr. and Lucie Arnaz.Special features in this set include spectacular colour footage of Ball's flying butterfly routine from Danny Thomas' "Wonderful World of Burlesque" TV special, original sponsorship bumps for selected episodes, an original CBS promo for Season Four, some behind-the-scenes footage from the "Marineland" episode; and guest star profiles.Episodes:Lucy at MarinelandLucy and the Golden GreekLucy in the Music WorldLucy and JoanLucy, the Stunt ManLucy and the Countess Have a Horse GuestLucy Helps Danny ThomasLucy Helps the CountessLucy and the Sleeping BeautyLucy and the Undercover AgentLucy and the Return of Iron ManLucy Saves Milton BerleLucy, the ChoirmasterLucy Discovers Wayne NewtonLucy, the Rain GoddessLucy and Art LinkletterLucy Bags a BargainLucy Meets Mickey RooneyLucy and the Soap OperaLucy Goes to a Hollywood PremiereLucy Dates Dean MartinLucy and Bob CraneLucy, the RobotLucy and Clint WalkerLucy, the Gun MollLucy, the Superwoman
summary: Lucy moves West in Season 4 of "The Lucy Show"

reviewText: I have to admit that I never liked Desi Arnaz much but I liked I Love Lucy. I love the Lucy Show a whole lot more. Lucy and Vivian Vance were great together and then others after. I couldn't wait for Season Four to arrive after purchasing the other three seasons. One reason that I love this season is for two episodes in particular is because of the episode titled "Lucy The Choir Master". It is a christmas episode to cherish and it's in color. From Lucy screwing up gift tags to her annoying a tree lot owner, to her trying to direct a childrens choir. Hilarious and heartwarming. This is much like the first seasons christmas classic Another favorite of mine is "Lucy Discovers Wayne Newton" where Wayne is only a teenager then and sings the song "Bessie The Heiffer". It is very cute and funny and is one of Lucy's favorites. I'd rather watch this any day over the new comedies. Lucy was a genius at comedy. Buy it for yourself. The episodes are great fun!!!
summary: "Absolucy Wonderful"

reviewText: The fourth season of "The Lucy Show" is a major turning point in the series.  Vivian Vance had quit at the end of season three so Lucy had to change formats.  I must say that the California Years have some of the best episodes of the series.  First of all, "The Lucy Show" finished a whopping third place in the Nielsen ratings for 1965-66 season.  It averaged a 27.7 rating and was way up from season three.  Season four also includes three more fabulous episodes with Ann Sothern as the Countess Framboise and one of the episodes include a cameo by William Frawley.  Actress Joan Blondell also stars in two episodes and both are great.  Season four of "The Lucy Show" changed for the better,  season three just couldn't go on any longer, especially with Vivian Vance's (I love her) demands.  Lucy was the star of the show and it showed by going it alone for the last nine years of her weekly television series career.  Gale Gordon's role is much larger now and Lucy will come to work for Banker Mooney as his secretary.  Lucy and Gale have a great chemistry together.  Mary Jane Croft will fill the void left by Vivian Vance.  The Mary Jane Lewis character is a real sweetheart.  She's sort of like an older Georiga Engel of "The Mary Tyler Moore Show."Season four garnerd Lucy her 11th Emmy Nomination for Best Actress In A Comedy Series and her second nomination for "The Lucy Show."  She will win two more Emmy's for the fifth and sixth seasons of "The Lucy Show."  There are a ton of classic episodes in season four that include:  Lucy In Marineland, Lucy In The Music World (classic Wing-Ding episde) a take-off of the Hullabaloo years, Lucy And The Golden Greek w/Howard Morris (hilarious), Lucy and Danny Thomas, Lucy and Dean Martin (another classic and one of Lucille Ball's favorite episodes), Lucy and Art Linkletter, two episodes with Clint Walker, Lucy the Gun Moll (w/Robert Stack) a take-off on "The Untouchables" and one of Lucy's best comedy performances ever, three episodes that introduces Lucy as Iron Man Carmichael (a stuntman)and Lucy goes to a Hollywood premiere w/cameos by Kirk Douglas, Edward G. Robinson and Vince Edwards.  All in all season four is GREAT and I applaud Lucille Ball for taking a chance and going it alone.  Her continuation with the Lucy character after Vivian Vance's departure proved that Lucy was the star of the show.  She went it alone and furter immortalized the Lucy character and her career.  Can't wait for season five when Lucy goes to London.
summary: Season Four - The California Years - JUST GREAT!

reviewText: I am so grateful that The Lucy Show Official 4th Season has been released on DVD. I love this season! Lucy's lovely 1960s California apartment is great (I always wanted to have an apartment like that one). The episodes are wonderful and I really enjoyed seeing Countess Framboise (Ann Sothern) in several of the episodes (it would have been great if Ann Sothern stayed until the end of The Lucy Show series but as noted here by another reviewer Ann Sothern wanted equal star billing with Lucy and Lucy was not going to have any of that! Too bad that Ann didn't accept a co-star billing but she wouldn't so that's the way the cookie crumbles). It was also nice to see Joan Blondell, Dean Martin, Wayne Newton and Mickey Rooney in this season. And the Wing Ding episode is one of my favorites of The Lucy Show series. All in glorious, perfectly presented CoLoR! I also loved the extra titled The Magic of Broadcasting included in this DVD set. Great work CBS! Now, when can we expect the Official 5th season?? I'll order as soon as it's announced. The Lucy Show is a series that I'm hoping to collect every season of so I can watch and watch again.

reviewText: Finally the Lucy Show Gets the Deluxe Treatment. For years we had to suffer with bad quality public domain versions of the Lucy Show. But now CBS is finally opening up the vaults and restoring these classic shows from the original master tapes. Every episode is full length and remastered and restored. In Season 4 we lose Vivian Vance and the kids from the original years are long gone. Gale Gordon and Lucy still manage to carry the show and the laughs are still there. If you have the other years you will definitely not be disappointed in season 4. I would highly recommend it! Very High Quality.
summary: The Lucy Show. Complete unedited shows that are remastered and fully restored.

reviewText: For fans of "The Lucy Show", this release of the series' fourth season is bittersweet. CBS is now rolling them out at a reasonable pace (it's been less than six months since Season 3 came out last November), but Season 4 marks a sharp turning point for the series.Fans of Vivian Vance will be especially disappointed. Having left the series at the end of Season 3, this year she only receives a two-second mention from Lucy in the season-opener ("I wonder how Viv likes her new husband"). Trying to find a replacement for the irreplaceable Viv was fruitless, so after an episode with Joan Blondell as a potential sidekick, Ann Sothern makes a few return appearances to fill the void before everyone probably decided "Oh, the hell with it" and gave up. From this point forward, whenever they needed an ear for Lucy's schemes, they called on good 'ol reliable, sweet Mary Jane Croft.Lucy's TV son Jerry is the only holdover from the Danfield era, but he is quickly whisked off to military school, leaving the Lucy character to adapt to her new surroundings in Hollywood and settle in with the series new "Guest-star-of-the-week" format (this season she meets Milton Berle, Danny Thomas, Mickey Rooney, Wayne Newton, Art Linkletter and Bob Crane to name but a few).Gale Gordon is forced to step up to the plate and becomes the principal co-star for Lucy for the remainder of the series. This is the season where he goes from managing her trust fund to becoming her employer at the bank, projecting frustration and his patented slow-burn in nearly every episode.All of these changes certainly do the show no favours. The earlier "Lucy Show" episodes quite often had the same energy and spark as "I Love Lucy", but these offerings are totally a horse of a different color altogether. Many fans have stated this may be the weakest season of "The Lucy Show". I may have to agree with that assessment, but there are still a few series highlights to be found here."Lucy In the Music World" is definitely one of those episodes to put in a 1960s time capsule to get a feel for the era. The musical "Wing-Ding" sequence is so wonderfully campy and fun that when it is reprised later in the show the viewer is delighted to see it, rather than annoyed that it could possibly have been used as filler to pad the running time.Totally un-politically-correct, but deserving credit as one of Lucy's most original and outrageous disguises is her portrayal of a Japanese gardener in the otherwise unremarkable "Lucy and the Soap Opera". It sure beats her trotting out the shaky little old lady schtick yet again (which she does anyway, incidentally)."Lucy Dates Dean Martin" was, for some reason, Ms. Ball's personal favorite of all "Lucy Show" episodes so that distinction alone makes it a curiosity.William "Fred Mertz" Frawley makes his final TV appearance in a cameo role in "Lucy and the Countess Have a Horse Guest" (which also features Ann Sothern). In both the Dino episode and this, Lucy changes her hairstyle to a slightly longer, more feminine Ann Landers-style for a few episodes, then reverts back to her famous '60s bubble-cut.In a spoof of "The Untouchables" Lucy gets to play a prancing, cheap gun moll opposite Robert Stack.Even if the episodes themselves this year are more often than not less-than-stellar Lucy (sometimes they have us laughing for the wrong reasons, as when Danny Thomas refers to his newest chorus girl, 54-year-old Lucy as "young lady"), CBS compensates by peppering these releases with enough bonus features and rare tidbits to keep fans satisfied. I am thrilled that this volume will contain Lucy's 1965 appearance in The Wonderful World of Burlesque. Here she dons a butterfly costume and prances along a tightrope above the audience. At one point, she seems to fall and the audience gasps in horror. I am unsure whether this was planned or not. I have this clip on an old VHS tape from 1991 called "A Tribute to Lucy", but the quality was very poor, like an old kinescope so it's great to have it restored here and IN COLOR!Among the other bonus features is a short promo for the show's color premiere in September 1965 (in poor condition) and priceless black-and-white behind-the-scenes footage of "Lucy at Marineland". We get to witness Lucille Ball and the director barking orders at each other, a frustrated Lucy reduced to tears because of all the retakes, and Lucy terrified when one of the dolphins decides to nuzzle her ear.Another worthwhile purchase for Lucy fans or those who love '60s comedy. All 26 episodes that originally aired during 1965-66 on Monday nights IN COLOR at 8:30 on CBS, beautifully remastered. Buy it--you're gonna have a "Wing-Ding"!
summary: "We're Gonna Have a Wing-Ding"

reviewText: Well, I just finished all four discs of "THE LUCY SHOW: The Official Fourth Season" last night, including all the extras. It is a wonderful collection.  The episodes are crisp and are a delight to watch.  The extras are lots of fun and always give you something special to look forward to; however, the editing on all the segments in each episode, meaning the beginning and end of each part from the beginning to each commercial break to the ending, were rushed/muted, making it sound muddy and unprofessional. I know this doesn't bother everybody, but it bothers me, because this is a professional studio that is making these new prints for DVD and they should sound as good as they look. All three previous seasons were great, except some episodes in season one had this situation, also.  I suspect the films were cut short and to avoid a harsh sound at each segment it was decided to use a muting method to make it sound less abrupt.  Being a fan of classic TV, I look foward to these series being as perfect as possible, but I just don't like it when the shows are altered like this.  Once again, it is a wonderful DVD collection.  If you love Lucy, you will not be disappointed.  I look forward to the release of seasons five and six in the very near future.
summary: CBS presents this program in color!!!

reviewText: Yep, this is just what I've come to expect from CBS/Paramount with 'The Lucy Show', just as they've done with the first 3 seasons, same excellent packaging, and boy does this season look crisp and clean with the picture, and sounds crystal clear, it's really amazing what they do with these old television series, for something thats about 50 years old, I mean wow, the colors are bright and vivid, the color practically jumps off the screen, and Lucys lovely red hair and blue eyes, boy she was really pretty, and she was in her mid to late 50's by now, and this season brings more of what we all love about Lucy, her antics and always getting into trouble.I remember watching the re-runs of this show on Nick at Nite back in the early to mid 1990's (along with Here's Lucy') and they really bring back a lot of memories for me, it's great to see these shows again, and being able to watch them in this pristine condition is a dream come true, it would seem that CBS/Paramount is trying to go alongside M.P.I. with the Here's Lucy seasons and trying to get them out around the same time, which is excellent as both companies are doing fantastic jobs, throw away those cheap public domain copies and get the real deal with these sets.So yes, once again, CBS/Paramount does a fantastic job as we would all expect, I look forward to season 5, keep them coming Paramount!
summary: Yep, more of the same from CBS/Paramount, and also a turning point for the series!

reviewText: Season Four of the Lucy Show(Sept/65-May/66),on four DVDs,as with the earlier seasons,are chock full of wonderful extras but the series itself was certainly starting to wind down.Although the ratings were decent you can tell the material is getting veneer thin in the laughs department.Lucy was a trooper however and any other comedienne would not have made it as far as a season four.Lucy had "it" and she had the best possible and strongest support in her endeavours from co-star Gale Gordon in the form of Mr Mooney her boss.To bolster her ratings though Lucy brought in a cadre of guest stars that year like Art Linkletter(remember just how big Art was for years?),a young and fresh faced Wayne Newton(just the way I like to remember this huge talent just as he hit the big time),Danny Thomas,Mickey Rooney,Dean Martin,Bob Crane and Bob Banner from Hogan's Heroes,and others.It is like watching a time capsule and it certainly brings back alot of memories.Of course this season like all the rest in this series comes with a plethora of extras like a segment of Arthur Godfrey's show looking at just how Lucy prepares for her shows,rare promo material,the vintage openings and closings c/w commercials(but not available as an option to start with them),biogs,photo galleries and much more.The eps have all been remastered and look clear and crisp.CBS/Paramount again do themselves and this series proud by going the extra mile in their presentation.A highly recommended release for all Lucy fans and a great time capsule for TV history buffs.The laughs are getting weaker but hey,we still love our Lucy.
summary: Lucy carries on into Season Four-although the laughs are more forced now

reviewText: No one knew what to expect in Season 4, after The Lucy Show Season 3 was a farewell to Vivian Vance. What they didn't expect from the show that was always in the top 10 Nielsen ratings, was that it would move up in the ratings to #3 after Vivian's departure, which it surprisingly did. The new Season 4 begins with Lucy moving to California and enlisting son Jerry in The Los Angeles Military School, while sending her daughter Chris up north to college. Lucy takes Jerry to Marineland to get Jimmy Piersall's autograph on Jimmy Piersall Day, all filmed at the real Marineland with the real Jimmy Piersall. What a great start to a season! Added to all this, you'll see Lucy perform with the seals and dolphins as well as seeing her real life children sitting behind her in the stands.Besides booking more great guest stars in this season, Lucy was still looking for that permanent new sidekick to replace Vivian. Lucy's close friend Ann Sothern was out of the question due to Ann's wanting equal top billing, so the search was still on. In the 4th episode, a new contender appeared in the show, Joan Blondell. Joan played Joan Brenner, who lives downstairs and works at the movie studios. Lucy didn't have an opinion on her from one episode, so she put Joan in the next episode, where Lucy's famous stunt man character Iron Man Carmichael was born. At the end of this second episode with Joan Blondell, Lucy was so disappointed in Joan's performances and the fact that they had no chemistry both on and off screen, that she imitated flushing a toilet in front of the audience. The audience gasped and Joan Blondell was so upset and insulted at the toilet flushing gesture that she shouted the mother of all words to Lucy, Blank (it rhymes with duck) You Lucille Ball! came out of her mouth. The audience was dead silent and Joan Blondell was never seen on any Lucy shows again. Unlike Danny Kaye who was upset at the notes Lucy would leave him on how to be a better comedian, Joan never forgave Lucy's toilet pantomime. So, to fill in those couple of Joan Blondell shows, Ann Sothern came in and helped out her old and dear friend Lucy in a pinch by appearing as the Countess.On Ann's first episode following the Blondell nightmare, William Frawley is given a short walk on part with a couple lines. No one knew that this would be Bill's final television appearance, as he would be dead in four short months. As Bill walks away from the horse stable, Lucy is given a great line, He reminds me of someone I used to know. A lot of people don't know that after the end of the I Love Lucy series, Desi and Lucy offered William Frawley and Vivian Vance the opportunity to have their own Fred and Ethel spin off series for Desilu. As much as Bill hated Vivian in real life, he said yes, but Vivian said she would never work with William Frawley ever again. Vivian hated Bill Frawley much more than he ever knew. Four months after this appearance by Bill on the Lucy Show, he collapsed on Hollywood Blvd. right in front of his apartment. He had just come from the movie theatre after seeing Inside Daisy Clover starring Natalie Wood. Bill loved the movies and even as ill as he had been after undergoing treatments from prostate cancer, he would still walk down the block to see a new movie playing. When he collapsed, his male nurse came running out from the apartment but could not revive him. He died of a massive heart attack at age 79. When Vivian Vance heard the news, she was eating dinner in a restaurant and yelled Yay, Fred is Dead! to the shock of the other customers. When Lucy heard the news, she said she lost one of her dearest friends and when Desi heard, he paid for a full page ad in the Hollywood Reporter and had Bill's photo and birth and death dates posted with 3 words- Buenos Noches Amigo!- in English, Good Night Friend. William Frawley was 22 years older than Vivian Vance and she hated that fact as much as she hated him. Lucy being only 2 years younger than Vivian in real life and having a husband 6 years younger than Lucy made it all the more obvious that the Ethel character got stuck with this really ancient old grumpy guy, and Vivian always hated it.After trying out Ann and Joan, Lucy decided that she would replace the irreplacable Vivian with two friends that had the chemistry she wanted - Mary Jane Croft and Gale Gordon. They alternated playing off Lucy in this season's episodes. Mary Jane got to play the character of Mary Jane Lewis, which is actually her real married name. She would be Lucy's next door neighbor and best friend, when ever Lucy needed her, and Mr. Mooney would move to California to be her part time, then full time boss whenever Lucy needed him. Now that Lucy had these 2 replacements for her beloved Vivian, the show could bring in those always wonderful guest stars. Mel Torme, Joan Blondell, Ann Sothern, Danny Thomas, Clint Walker, Jack Cassidy, Milton Berle, Wayne Newton, Jamie Farr, Art Linkletter, Mickey Rooney, Jan Murray, Reta Shaw, Dean Martin, Bob Crane, John Banner, Jay North, Robert Stack, Bruce Gordon and all those great huge stars that walk on in Lucy Goes To A Hollywood Premiere, made this show a must tune in and see for much of 1960's America. When asked what was Lucy's favorite show, Lucy answered the Lucy Meets Dean Martin episode from this season. Many people don't know why Lucy chose this show- was it because they were family friends with their sons in the Dino, Desi and Billy band? Or perhaps because they had great chemistry together and enjoyed each others sense of humor, as you could see years later in those Dean Martin Roasts? Maybe those were part of the reasons, but the real reason was Lucy ADORED Frank Sinatra, Bobby Darrin and Dean Martin's singing to no end. Watch the episode in this season, when Dean sings to Lucy- she LOVES IT! She has the same look on her face as when she looks at Frank Sinatra from the audience in his television specials. Lucy loved great singers and Dean just made her season this year!I again cannot thank CBS enough for bringing these beloved episodes into our homes pristinely cleaned up and with extra treasures! This is another great Season of The Lucy Show that you will love!UPDATE AUGUST 2011 FOR SEASON 5:  Just spoke to a CBS rep and Season 5 of The Lucy Show will be available this December 2011- just in time for Christmas! MPI has also stated they would like to have Season 5 of Here's Lucy available at the end of 2011 as well, but have not mentioned a release date yet. CBS said Lucy In London will definitely be released, but do not know if it will be included with Season 5 or available separately. CBS said they have been busy cleaning up old Lucy films that will be included in these last 2 Seasons- and the last Season 6 will be available in 2012! This will be a Very Merry 2011 Lucy Christmas for us Lucy Fans, if we get both Season 5's! THANK YOU CBS!!!SEASON 4 EPISODES:01.  09-13-1965  LUCY AT MARINELAND- Lucy moves to California and enlists son Jerry in the Los Angeles Military School. They spend the day at Marineland and get Jimmy Piersall's autograph. (Jimmy Piersall and Harvey Korman guest star; watch for Lucie Arnaz and Desi Jr. sitting behind Lucy in the stands)02.  09-20-1965  LUCY AND THE GOLDEN GREEK- Lucy's new neighbor Mary Jane Lewis gets Lucy a blind date with a shy, short lifeguard who changes when he hears Greek music. (Howard Morris and Mary Jane Croft guest star)03.  09-27-1965  LUCY IN THE MUSIC WORLD- Lucy gets her struggling songwriter neighbor a job on The Wing Ding Show, after they update his song. They sing as The Tearducts duo. (Mel Torme guest stars)04.  10-11-1965  LUCY AND JOAN- Lucy's neighbor downstairs, Joan Brenner who works in pictures, invites Lucy to the Screen Arts Charity Ball, if they can find her a date. (Joan Blondell guest stars)05.  10-18-1965  LUCY, THE STUNT MAN- Lucy buys a new leopard coat and when Mr. Mooney won't give her the money to pay for it, neighbor Joan Brenner gets her a job that pays well for a day- as a stuntman. (Joan Blondell guest stars)06.  10-25-1965  LUCY AND THE COUNTESS HAVE A HORSE GUEST- The Countess shows up at Lucy's door, broke, with her luggage and a horse. (Ann Sothern guest stars with a walk on by William Frawley)07.  11-01-1965  LUCY HELPS DANNY THOMAS- Lucy delivers bank documents to The Danny Thomas Show, where she gets chosen to be a showgirl by Danny. (Danny Thomas guest stars)08.  11-08-1965  LUCY HELPS THE COUNTESS- The Countess gets a job in real estate and Lucy tries to help with her commission, by showing Mr. Mooney an apartment. The 3 get locked in by accident with no food for the night. (Ann Sothern guest stars)09.  11-15-1965  LUCY AND THE SLEEPING BEAUTY- Lucy meets Frank the builder at a construction site and they start to date, only Frank can't stay awake after a hard day's work. (Clint Walker, Mary Jane Croft and Mary Wickes guest star)10.  11-22-1965  LUCY, THE UNDERCOVER AGENT- After viewing a James Bond movie, Lucy and the Countess become suspicious of everyone. Lucy does a wonderful imitation of Carol Channing! (Ann Sothern and Jack Cassidy guest star)11.  11-29-1965  LUCY AND THE RETURN OF THE IRON MAN- When Mr. Mooney ducks out of the horse races, he leaves his ticket with Lucy who tears it up. When the horse wins, Lucy must come up with the money by becoming Iron Man for the day. (Mary Jane Croft guest stars)12.  12-06-1965  LUCY SAVES MILTON BERLE- Lucy and Mary Jane volunteer at a soup kitchen when they try and help Milton Berle (pretending to be his own brother), who is actually getting in character for an upcoming role. (Milton Berle and Mary Jane Croft guest star)13.  12-13-1965  LUCY, THE CHOIRMASTER- Son Jerry comes home for Christmas and Lucy arranges a Christmas Choir with The St. Charles Boys Choir and Mr. Mooney sings bass.14.  12-27-1965  LUCY DISCOVERS WAYNE NEWTON- Wayne finds Mr. Mooney's dog Nelson on his farm and when Lucy comes to retrieve him, she discovers a new singing sensation. (Wayne Newton and Gary Morton guest star)15.  01-03-1966  LUCY, THE RAIN GODDESS- When Lucy brings papers up to a western hotel near a Native American reservation for Mr. Mooney to sign, she is recognized as a rain goddess, and she must make it rain or die. (Jamie Farr guest stars)16.  01-10-1966  LUCY AND ART LINKLETTER- Lucy is challenged by The Art Linkletter Show to not speak for 24 hours to win a $200.00 cash prize. (Art Linkletter guest stars)17.  01-17-1966  LUCY BAGS A BARGAIN- When Lucy buys a dinette set on sale, she finds out the price is more than she thought and gets a job at the store to pay for it.18.  01-24-1966  LUCY MEETS MICKEY ROONEY- Mr. Mooney finances Mickey Rooney's Acting School and he and Lucy take lessons. They end up doing a Chaplin silent. (Mickey Rooney guest stars)19.  01-31-1966  LUCY AND THE SOAP OPERA- Lucy's neighbor doesn't know if he will have a job if he gets written out of a soap, so Lucy tries to sneakily find out from the writer what the outcome will be. (Jan Murray and Mary Jane Croft guest star)20.  02-07-1966  LUCY GOES TO A HOLLYWOOD PREMIERE- Lucy's friend is moving and Lucy takes over her corner selling movie star maps. When the friend's son drops off his usher's uniform for a Hollywood Premeire, Lucy gets her chance of a lifetime to be up close with the stars. (Reta Shaw guest stars with walk ons by Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. Robinson, Kirk Douglas, Jimmy and Margie Durante and Vincent Edwards)21.  02-14-1966  LUCY MEETS DEAN MARTIN- Mary Jane arranges for Dean Martin's double Eddie Feldman to take Lucy to a fancy Hollywood Charity Ball. When Eddie must work, the real Dean fills in. (Dean Martin and Mary Jane Croft guest star)22.  02-21-1966  LUCY AND BOB CRANE- Bob Crane meets Lucy at the bank and takes her out for a date, not knowing her Iron Man identity on his movie set. (Bob Crane and John Banner (Sgt. Schultz) guest star)23.  02-28-1966  LUCY, THE ROBOT- After six baby sitters can't deal with Mr. Mooney's unruly nephew, Lucy takes over with her own robotic protection. (Jay North guest stars)24.  03-07-1966  LUCY AND CLINT WALKER- Lucy makes Frank the builder a red sweater, only finds out he hates red. Frank's dog Lightning the beagle saves the day. (Clint Walker and  Mary Jane Croft guest star)25.  03-14-1966  LUCY, THE GUN MOLL- The FBI finds that Lucy is a look-alike for a gangster's moll and gets her to pose as his girlfriend Rusty Martin to find out where he hid the loot. (Robert Stack and Bruce Gordon (Big Nick) guest star)26.  03-21-1966  LUCY, THE SUPERWOMAN- When a one ton computer falls on Mr. Mooney's foot, Lucy makes headlines when she lifts it off. (Mary Jane Croft guest stars)
summary: CALIFORNIA, MARY JANE, IRON MAN, BILL'S LAST APPEARANCE
Title: N/A

reviewText: By the fall of 1965 "The Lucy Show" was completely revamped. Vivian Vance quit because she wasn't able to have more control over what her character did and she wanted to spend more time on the east coast with her husband. Since Viv was gone her son Sherman disappeared too. Lucy's two children were written out and the series locale was changed to Los Angeles. For viewers of color TV CBS started airing "The Lucy Show" in color this year. Despite these changes "The Lucy Show" continued to thrive because of the comedic chomps of Lucille Ball that proved she was indeed the star of this series and she was the reason viewers were tuning in by the millions. The series finished the 1965/1966 year as the 3rd highest rated series on American network television.Since Vivian Vance was no longer part of the cast Lucille Ball decided to have guest stars in the remaining seasons of the show as she felt no one in her heart could replace Viv. This year saw a who's who of Hollywood stars that graced "The Lucy Show", everyone from Dean Martin to Milton Berle.The fourth season box set, however, doesn't contain much in the way of bonuses, but does include cast biographies, production notes, and photo galleries.The following is a list of the 26 episodes from "The Lucy Show's" season 4 along with airdates:1. "Lucy at Marineland", Sept. 13, 19652. "Lucy and the Golden Greek", Sept. 20, 19653. "Lucy in the Music World", Sept. 27, 19654. "Lucy and Joan", Oct. 11, 19655. "Lucy, The Stunt Man", Oct. 18, 19656. "Lucy and the Countess Have A Horse Guest", Oct. 25, 19657. "Lucy Helps Danny Thomas", Nov. 1, 19658. "Lucy Helps the Countess", Nov. 18, 19659. "Lucy and the Sleeping Beauty", Nov. 15, 196510. "Lucy, the Undercover Agent", Nov. 22, 196511. "Lucy and the Return of the Iron Man", Nov. 29, 196512. "Lucy Saves Milton Berle", Dec. 6, 196513. "Lucy, the Choirmaster", Dec. 13, 196514. "Lucy Discovers Wayne Newton", Dec. 27, 196515. "Lucy, the Rain Goddess", Jan. 3, 196616. "Lucy and Art Linkletter", Jan. 10, 196617. "Lucy Bags a Bargain", Jan. 17, 196618. "Lucy Meets Mickey Rooney", Jan. 24, 196619. "Lucy and the Soap Opera", Jan 31, 196620. "Lucy Goes To A Hollywood Premiere", Feb. 7, 196621. "Lucy Dates Dean Martin", Feb. 14, 196622. "Lucy and Bob Crane", Feb. 21, 196623. "Lucy, The Robot", Feb. 28, 196624. "Lucy and Clint Walker", March 7, 196625. "Lucy, the Gun Moll", March 14, 196626. "Lucy, the Superwoman", March 21, 1966
summary: "California Lucy!"

reviewText: This certainly is a fine restoration.  All is very crisp and clear;  as well as funny!  If you are a devoted LUCY fan-  then this will come on the top of your list.  I  was amazed at the clarity of these shows. CBS/PARAMOUNT dida first class job getting these done with top-notch quality.  A few times the picture was so clear that i thoughtthat I  saw the pits in Lucys skin !!  You will really enjoy the antics that Lucille Ball is known so well for inthis Official release.Thank-you CBS/PARAMOUNT !  I  am ready to purchase the remaining seasons !!!!
summary: Great Restoration
